headline: Big Oil earnings show split in production strategy, shareholder returns
summary: HOUSTON/LONDON (Reuters) -Big Oil's first-quarter earnings have shown a clear split in how companies are positioned to weather the downturn sparked by a slump in oil prices to a four-year low in April.  Investors were focused on whether companies would cut share repurchases, since lower crude prices would leave them with less cash to fund the programs.  Buybacks and dividends are key to investor interest in the oil industry.

raw.headline: Big Oil earnings show split in production strategy, shareholder returns
raw.summary: HOUSTON/LONDON (Reuters) -Big Oil's first-quarter earnings have shown a clear split in how companies are positioned to weather the downturn sparked by a slump in oil prices to a four-year low in April.  Investors were focused on whether companies would cut share repurchases, since lower crude prices would leave them with less cash to fund the programs.  Buybacks and dividends are key to investor interest in the oil industry.

headline: Here are the latest companies warning about tariffs
summary: Executives are increasingly warning about tariffs either in their earnings releases or on the earnings calls. Exxon Mobil (XOM), Eaton (ETN), and Apollo Global Management (APO) leaders are just a few of the latest to do so. In the video above, Market Domination Overtime Anchor Julie Hyman recaps what they said. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination Overtime here. Note: Apollo Global Management is the parent company of Yahoo Finance.

headline: Chevron Cuts Buybacks As Oil Plunges
summary: Chevron and Exxon reported high earnings even after Chevron said it would reduce it's share buybacks because of tumbling oil prices and a trade war. Meanwhile, Exxon is sticking with its's share buyback plans as it's earnings met analysts' estimates. Goldman Sachs Head of North American Natural Equity Research Neil Mehta has more on the story.

headline: Oil Falls as OPEC+ Weighs Another Major Production Increase
summary: (Bloomberg) -- Oil slumped as OPEC+ discussed making a second major production increase, inflaming concerns about swelling global supplies that have dragged down crude prices this year. headline: Chevron signals readiness to integrate Hess, downplays Exxon arbitration risk
summary: Investing.com -- After reporting solid Q1 results, Chevron Corp (NYSE:CVX) highlighted strategic progress across its operations while reaffirming confidence in its $53 billion acquisition of Hess Corporation (NYSE:HES). CEO Mike Wirth told Bloomberg Television the company is fully prepared to integrate Hess “very quickly” once it clears an arbitration case with Exxon Mobil Corp (NYSE:XOM), which claims a right of first refusal over Hess’s stake in Guyana’s massive oil field.

headline: Exxon Sticks With Plans for Stock Buybacks, Capex, as Oil Slides
summary: Exxon  Mobil is pushing full-throttle ahead on its growth plans, even as the oil market is teetering.  Earnings per share came in at $1.76, compared with a median analyst estimate of $1.75.  Oil prices have slumped below $60 per barrel, near four-year lows, because of worry that tariffs will hurt demand even as OPEC raises production.

headline: Exxon & Chevron earnings, energy challenges under Trump 2.0
summary: Exxon (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) posted earnings beats on Friday, but low oil prices (CL=F, BZ=F) weigh on the industry. The Energy Word founder, Daniel Dicker, tells Morning Brief co-hosts Brad Smith and Madison Mills that the energy sector — including natural gas and sustainable options like solar — is uninvestable under Trump 2.0. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief here.

headline: Chevron Makes This Surprise Move In Guyana Contest With Exxon Mobil
summary: Exxon Mobil and Chevron reported better-than-expected first-quarter profit early Friday. Meanwhile, Chevron stressed shareholder value, returning nearly $7 billion to stockholders in Q1 but plans to reduce that amount in the second quarter.

headline: Profits at American oil giants Exxon Mobil and Chevron fall in tandem with waning energy demand
summary: The oil and gas giant earned $7.71 billion, or $1.76 per share, for the three months ended March 31.  The results topped Wall Street expectations, but Exxon does not adjust its reported results based on one-time events such as asset sales.  Analysts polled by Zacks Investment Research expected earnings of $1.74 per share.

headline: Exxon beats Wall Street profit estimate, boosted by Guyana and Permian production
summary: HOUSTON (Reuters) -Exxon Mobil on Friday beat Wall Street's estimate for first-quarter profit as higher oil and gas production from Guyana and the Permian basin helped boost earnings.  The buyback figure puts Exxon on track to meet its annual share repurchase goal of $20 billion.  "In this uncertain market, our shareholders can be confident in knowing that we're built for this," Exxon CEO Darren Woods said in a statement.

The buyback figure puts Exxon on track to meet its annual share repurchase goal of $20 billion.  "In this uncertain market, our shareholders can be confident in knowing that we're built for this," Exxon CEO Darren Woods said in a statement.
